summary_points: 1. On May 1, 2025, Church & Dwight Co., Inc. held its Annual Meeting of Stockholders, where all proposed director nominees were elected and the appointment of Deloitte & Touche LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for 2025 was ratified.

2.  Significant stockholder opposition was registered against several director nominees, ranging from 3.9 million (Richard A. Dierker) to 21.7 million votes (Penry W. Price) cast against their election; a stockholder proposal (Proposal No. 4) received only 27.8 million votes in favor versus 165.1 million against.

3.  The advisory vote to approve compensation of the named executive officers passed with 171.4 million votes in favor, but 21.7 million votes against, suggesting ongoing concerns regarding executive compensation.
1. As of April 28th, 2025, PACCAR Inc. awarded Long Term Performance Cash Awards totaling $38,861,714 to its Named Executive Officers, significantly increasing their total compensation.

2. At the April 29th, 2025, annual meeting, a shareholder proposal regarding excessive golden parachutes failed to receive a majority vote, with 145,604,574 shares voting "For" and 311,616,163 voting "Against".
3.  The CEO-to-median-employee pay ratio for PACCAR Inc. in 2024 was 189:1, with the CEO's total compensation at $17,364,223 and the median employee's at $91,985.

1. On May 2, 2025, Henry Schein Inc. and KKR entered into a letter agreement to remove KKR's voting commitment from their January 29, 2025, Strategic Partnership Agreement, leaving the rest of the agreement unchanged.

2.  Max Lin was appointed to Henry Schein's board of directors on May 2, 2025, increasing the board size to 15; he will receive standard cash director compensation payable to KKR, but no equity compensation.
3. Mr. Lin's appointment, effective April 10, 2025, was contingent upon KKR satisfying certain regulatory conditions under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act and receiving approvals from Sweden and Italy.
1. Gallagher's Q1 2025 revenue increased 15% year-over-year to $3,727.4 million, driven in part by 11 acquisitions totaling $100.9 million in annualized revenue.
2. The $13.45 billion AssuredPartners acquisition, expected to close in the second half of 2025, is facing regulatory delays due to a request for additional information.
3. Gallagher anticipates $494.3 million in amortizable intangible asset expenses for the remainder of 2025, with further expenses projected through 2030.

1. Wynn Resorts' 2025 Annual Meeting (April 30, 2025) resulted in the election of three Class II directors (Craig S. Billings, Anthony M. Sanfilippo, and Winifred M. Webb) and the ratification of Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor.

2.  Shareholder proposals to approve executive compensation and to commission a report on smoke-free policies received significantly different levels of support: 64,070,421 votes for, versus 5,764,552 votes for, respectively.
3. The overwhelmingly negative vote on the shareholder proposal regarding a smoke-free policy suggests a lack of immediate board action on the issue.

1. On May 1, 2025, ERP Operating Limited Partnership agreed to issue $500,000,000 of 4.950% Notes due June 15, 2032, in a public offering underwritten by several firms including Citigroup, J.P. Morgan, RBC Capital Markets, and Wells Fargo.
2. The Notes will be sold at 99.716% of the principal amount to the public, generating net proceeds of $495,455,000 before expenses.
3. The Issuer may redeem the Notes prior to April 15, 2032, at a redemption price including accrued interest and a Make-Whole Amount calculated using a Treasury rate plus 15 basis points.

1. On April 29, 2025, Becton, Dickinson and Company amended its bylaws to update procedural and disclosure requirements related to shareholder nominations and business at annual meetings, aligning with Rule 14a-19.
2. The filing mentions several notes with varying due dates and interest rates, including 3.020% Notes due May 24, 2025, and 0.034% Notes due August 13, 2025.

3. The amended bylaws (Exhibit 3) introduce stricter requirements for shareholder proposals and nominations, including minimum ownership thresholds and advanced notice periods, potentially limiting shareholder activism.
1. Western Digital Corp. completed the separation of its HDD and Flash business units on February 21, 2025.
2.  Net revenue increased 31% year-over-year for the quarter ended March 28, 2025, driven by a 23% price increase.
3. WDC expects to sell its 19.9% stake in SanDisk by May 2, 2026.
1. Ingersoll Rand Inc.'s net income decreased by $15.7 million year-over-year to $186.5 million in the quarter ended March 31, 2025, primarily due to increased expenses.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, there is an elevated impairment risk for goodwill and intangible assets in two Precision and Science Technologies reporting units due to the recent ILC Dover acquisition.
3. On May 1, 2025, Ingersoll Rand Inc. increased its share repurchase program authorization by $1 billion, bringing the total to $1.993 billion.

1.  On April 30, 2025, Expeditors International of Washington, Inc. (the “Company”) entered into an employment agreement with its new Chief Executive Officer, Daniel R. Wall, establishing an annual base salary of $100,000 and outlining incentive-based compensation and severance benefits.
2. There are no related party transactions requiring disclosure under Item 404(a) of Regulation S-K.
3. The employment agreement with the new CEO includes a six-month non-compete and 12-month non-solicitation clause.
1. Extra Space Storage Inc. acquired 27 properties in April 2025 for a total consideration of $411,174 ($153,174 cash and $258,000 assumed debt).
2. Revenue for Q1 2025 increased by 2.6% year-over-year.
3.  The company is assessing the impact of ASU No. 2024-03, with compliance needed by December 31, 2027.
1. On May 2, 2025, Exelon Corporation announced a plan to sell up to $2,500,000,000 of its common stock.
2. Exelon may use forward sale transactions to mitigate risks associated with this equity distribution plan.
3. The success of Exelon's equity distribution plan is uncertain due to market conditions and investor demand.

1. Entergy Corporation held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 2, 2025, where shareholders elected directors, ratified Deloitte & Touche LLP as the independent auditor, and approved executive compensation.
2.  For Proposal 1 (Election of Directors), the number of votes cast against the nominees ranged from 966,911 to 14,709,856, with significant variations among the nominees.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks were identified in this section of the filing.
1. Everest Group's net income plummeted 71.4% year-over-year to $210 million in Q1 2025.
2.  Losses from the Washington D.C. aviation accident contributed $83 million to the $208 million increase in attritional losses during Q1 2025.
3.  A potential Bermuda tax law change, responding to OECD guidance issued January 15, 2025, may reduce Everest Group's deferred tax assets, though the extent of the impact remains unknown.
1. Anthony Welters resigned from Loews Corporation's Board of Directors on May 1, 2025, reducing the board's size from eleven to ten directors.
2.  The filing is intended to simultaneously satisfy the filing obligation under Rule 14a-12 for soliciting material.
3. Loews Corporation's 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders is scheduled for May 13, 2025.
1. On April 28, 2025, Cintas Corp issued $400,000,000 in 4.200% Senior Notes due 2028, guaranteed by Cintas Corporation and certain subsidiaries.
2.  The Notes were sold at a purchase price of 99.522% of the principal amount plus accrued interest.

3. The underwriting agreement includes indemnification provisions between Cintas Corp and the underwriters, which cover potential liabilities arising from untrue statements or omissions in the offering documents.

1. At IBM's April 29, 2025, annual shareholder meeting,  A.N. Liveris received significantly fewer votes in favor of his directorship (492,110,122) compared to other directors, suggesting potential concerns among shareholders.
2.  The stockholder proposal to support transparency in lobbying received only 18.9% of the vote, indicating strong opposition from shareholders to this initiative.
3. The shareholder proposal requesting a report on hiring/recruitment discrimination was withdrawn by the proponent.
1. On May 1, 2025, Karen Dahut resigned from DexCom's Board of Directors, effective May 8, 2025, with the resignation not resulting from any disagreement.
2.  The SEC filing is an 8-K Current Report, filed on May 2nd, 2025.

1. Solventum Corp held its annual shareholder meeting on April 30, 2025, where shareholders elected four Class I nominees to the Board of Directors and approved, on an advisory basis, the compensation of Solventum's Named Executive Officers.
2.  Shareholders voted for an annual advisory vote on executive compensation, with 135,522,957 votes in favor of a yearly vote versus 262,972 for a two-year vote and 1,071,704 for a three-year vote.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as Solventum's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.

1. Marathon Petroleum Corp's 2025 Annual Meeting, held on April 30th 2025, saw shareholders elect four Class II directors and ratify PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor for the year ending December 31, 2025.
2.  A proposal to declassify the Board of Directors and another to eliminate supermajority provisions both failed to receive the required 80% affirmative vote at the April 30th 2025 annual meeting.
3. A shareholder proposal seeking a simple majority vote was not approved, receiving only 102,780,412 votes for compared to 108,974,674 votes against as of April 30th, 2025.
1. Ameriprise Financial Inc.'s 2025 annual shareholder meeting on April 30, 2025, saw 87.88% of outstanding shares represented, with votes cast on director elections and executive compensation.
2.  Significant opposition votes were cast against several director nominees (ranging from 157,274 to 7,008,183 votes against, out of approximately 76-81 million votes for each candidate).
3. Shareholder advisory approval of named executive officer compensation was secured with 69,497,675 votes in favor compared to 8,956,663 votes against.
1. Merck faces a potential $1.3 billion increase in transition tax liability plus $260 million in penalties from the IRS, as of April 2025.
2.  Merck's acquisition of the WuXi Vaccines facility in Dundalk, Ireland, was finalized in March 2025 for a total cost of $759 million.
3.  Merck licensed HRS-5346 from Hengrui Pharma in March 2025 for an upfront payment of $200 million, with potential future payments up to $1.7 billion.
1. Seagate's revenue increased by $2 billion in the nine months ending March 28, 2025, compared to the same period in 2024.
2.  Seagate acquired Intevac, Inc. for $118 million on March 31, 2025.
3.  By July 2, 2027, Seagate must reduce its net leverage ratio to 4.25 to 1.00.
1. Norfolk Southern Corp completed a $400,000,000 offering of 5.100% Senior Notes due 2035 on May 2, 2025.
2.  The Notes pay semi-annual interest at a rate of 5.100% per annum and mature on May 1, 2035.

3. The Notes include a Change of Control Repurchase Event, triggering a repurchase offer at 101% of principal plus accrued interest if a change of control occurs and the notes are downgraded below investment grade.
1. On April 28th, 2025, Colgate-Palmolive issued $500,000,000 in 4.200% Senior Notes due 2030.
2. The notes were sold at 99.597% of their face value, and the offering closed on May 2nd, 2025.
3.  The offering was made under an existing indenture dated November 15, 1992, with The Bank of New York Mellon acting as trustee.
1. Blackstone's net income decreased 27% year-over-year to $614.85 million in Q1 2025.
2.  Blackstone anticipates $2 billion in payments under tax receivable agreements over the next 15 years.
3.  Blackstone repurchased 0.2 million shares for $31 million in Q1 2025, leaving $1.8 billion remaining in its share repurchase program as of March 31, 2025.
1. Ameriprise Financial's Q1 2025 net income decreased by 41% year-over-year, primarily due to a $460 million expense from market impacts on long-duration products.
2.  Ameriprise received a new $4.5 billion common stock repurchase authorization on April 22, 2025,  with $271 million remaining under a prior authorization as of March 31, 2025.
3. Ameriprise's total equity could decrease by $571 million as of March 31, 2025, if the nonperformance credit spread on its market risk benefits reaches zero.
1. AIG's net income for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, decreased by 42% year-over-year to $698 million, primarily due to the deconsolidation of Corebridge Financial and higher catastrophe losses.
2. AIG's holdings of below investment-grade bonds increased by $1.9 billion between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025, reaching $5.5 billion (8%).
3. AIG faces potential liquidity issues due to the possibility of needing to provide additional collateral for Corebridge Financial's debt instruments.
1. Mohawk Industries Inc. experienced a $153.6 million decrease in net sales from Q1 2024 to Q1 2025, attributed to fewer shipping days, unfavorable exchange rates, and system conversion issues.
2.  The company faces a potential EUR 1.0 billion tax assessment in Belgium.
3.  Mohawk anticipates additional restructuring costs of $40-$55 million in 2025 and 2026.
1. As of April 30, 2025, Coca-Cola Company shareholders elected eleven individuals to the board of directors, with approval percentages ranging from 77% to 99%.
2.  Shareholder proposals at the April 30, 2025 annual meeting received between 0.84% and 12.47% affirmative votes, with the majority of proposals failing to pass.
3. The SEC filing indicates that Coca-Cola Co. is not an emerging growth company as defined in Rule 405 of the Securities Act of 1933.
1. Teradyne's Q1 2025 revenue increased by $85.8 million (14.3%) year-over-year to $685.7 million.
2.  A restructuring of the Robotics organization in Q1 2025 resulted in $11.4 million in employee severance charges.
3. Teradyne plans to repurchase up to $1 billion of its common stock in 2025 and 2026, contingent on market conditions.
1. Camden Property Trust's Q1 2025 net income decreased by $45.1 million compared to Q1 2024, primarily due to a one-time gain on a property sale in Q1 2024.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, the company plans to spend approximately $350.7 million to complete construction on four properties.
3.  A new 12-year corporate headquarters lease, commencing in Q4 2025, will cost approximately $29.6 million in minimum payments.
1. PNC's Q1 2025 net income decreased 8% year-over-year to $1.5 billion.
2.  Recent trade policy changes are expected to significantly weaken 2025 economic growth, resulting in real GDP growth below 1% and unemployment potentially exceeding 5% (as of May 2nd, 2025).
3. PNC expects to reclassify $0.3 billion (after-tax) in net derivative losses from AOCI to interest income in the twelve months following March 31, 2025.
1. Eaton's Q1 2025 net income increased by 17.5% year-over-year to $964 million, driven partly by strong data center and utility sales.
2. The acquisition of Fibrebond Corporation on April 1, 2025, for $1.45 billion, will result in $240 million in employee retention award expenses spread over six years.
3.  Eaton plans to spend $900 million on capital expenditures in 2025 to increase production capacity, while also incurring $475 million in restructuring charges through 2026.
1. Q1 2025 revenue increased by 8.4% year-over-year to $1.59 billion, driven by higher room rates and strong group business, despite the temporary closure of The Don CeSar.
2.  Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc. repaid a $79 million loan in February 2025.
3.  The company's  RevPAR growth guidance for 2025 remains 0.5% to 2.5%, despite a lowered U.S. GDP growth forecast of 1.4% (as of May 2, 2025).
1. T. Rowe Price's Q1 2025 diluted earnings per share decreased by 13.7% year-over-year to $2.15.
2.  The firm anticipates significant future payments related to the 2021 OHA acquisition, totaling up to $900 million between 2026 and 2027.
3.  $282 million in capital expenditures are planned for 2025, with a substantial portion (85%) dedicated to technology.
1. Stryker's cash and cash equivalents decreased significantly from $3,652 million on December 31, 2024, to $2,320 million by March 31, 2025.
2. The Inari acquisition, completed in February 2025, resulted in a $139 million charge to selling, general, and administrative expenses in Q1 2025.
3. Stryker projects amortization expenses of $695 million in 2026, gradually decreasing to $609 million by 2029.
1. C.H. Robinson's Q1 2025 revenue decreased 8.3% year-over-year to $4.0 billion, primarily due to the sale of its Europe Surface Transportation business and lower ocean service pricing.
2. The sale of the Europe Surface Transportation business resulted in a $2.4 million pre-tax loss in Q1 2025.
3.  C.H. Robinson has $23.9 million in unrecognized tax benefits as of March 31, 2025, expected to decrease by approximately $1.1 million in the next 12 months.
1. Cigna Group sold its Medicare Advantage business for $4.8 billion in March 2025.
2.  Cigna's Q1 2025 shareholder net income increased by $1.6 billion compared to Q1 2024, mainly due to the absence of significant investment losses in the current quarter.
3.  Cigna anticipates incurring charges of at least $161 million through Q1 2025 related to restructuring, and further charges through December 2026 for its strategic optimization program.
1. Corning's net sales increased 16% year-over-year to $3,452 million in the three months ended March 31, 2025.
2.  Corning acquired a US-based manufacturing business in April 2025 for approximately $129 million.
3. A new finance lease for production equipment, valued at approximately $261 million, was signed in Q1 2025 and is expected to commence late 2026.

1. Mettler Toledo's net sales decreased by 5% year-over-year in USD for the three months ended March 31, 2025, although this was offset by a 3% increase in local currency excluding prior-year shipping delays.
2. New tariffs enacted in 2025 are estimated to increase Mettler Toledo's annual costs by approximately $115 million.
3.  Mettler Toledo's segment profit decreased from $267.3 million in Q1 2024 to $236.7 million in Q1 2025.

1. At Kimberly-Clark Corp's 2025 Annual Meeting on May 1, 2025, all director nominees were elected, Deloitte & Touche LLP was ratified as the independent auditor for 2025, and named executive officer compensation was approved on an advisory basis.
2.  The advisory vote on named executive officer compensation received 226,830,430 votes for, 17,437,076 votes against, and 1,645,615 abstentions.

3. While the filing doesn't state specific future impacts or risks, the results of the shareholder votes provide insight into the current support for the company's leadership, compensation structure, and auditor selection.

1. Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. announced an additional $120 million in restructuring charges as of May 2, 2025, primarily impacting the Laboratory Products and Biopharma Services segment, with further actions planned.
2.  Q1 2025 GAAP diluted earnings per share increased 15% year-over-year to $3.98.
3. The company plans to acquire Solventum Corporation's Purification & Filtration business for approximately $4.1 billion, expected to close by the end of 2025.
1. DuPont is restructuring into two segments (ElectronicsCo and IndustrialsCo) effective Q1 2025, with the separation of its Electronics business planned for November 1, 2025.
2.  DuPont's 2024 net sales increased by 3% year-over-year to $12.4 billion, but incurred a $199 million pre-tax charge related to its 2023-2024 Restructuring Program.
3.  DuPont anticipates $660 million in capital expenditures for 2025, including separation costs, and a $14 million increase in long-term employee benefit expense compared to 2024.
1. DuPont's Q1 2025 net loss of $582 million is largely attributable to a $768 million non-cash goodwill impairment charge, contrasting sharply with a $197 million net income in Q1 2024.
2.  The separation of DuPont's Electronics business, targeted for completion by November 1, 2025, is expected to incur $100 million in pre-tax restructuring charges through 2026.
3. DuPont's assets of continuing operations decreased by $655 million between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025, totaling $35.981 billion as of the latter date.

1. Smurfit Westrock plc's 2025 Annual General Meeting, held on May 2, 2025, resulted in shareholder approval of all director nominees (with between 98.16% and 99.78% voting for each nominee) and proposals 2 and 4-7.
2.  Proposal 3, regarding the frequency of future advisory votes on executive compensation, received 98.73% support for annual votes,  despite a requirement for such votes every six years.

3. The board of directors has decided that the company will conduct an annual advisory vote on executive compensation until the next required vote on the frequency of such votes in six years' time (from May 2, 2025).
1. Franklin Resources Inc.'s AUM decreased by 6% year-over-year as of March 31, 2025.
2.  A $24.4 million impairment charge was recorded in Q1 2025.
3.  As of May 2, 2025, Franklin Resources Inc.'s $1.1 billion revolving credit agreement has expired.

1. Franklin Resources, Inc. reported net income of $151.4 million ($0.26 per diluted share) for the fiscal quarter ending March 31, 2025, a 7% decrease from the previous quarter and a 22% increase year-over-year.
2. Long-term net outflows totaled $26.2 billion in the quarter ending March 31, 2025, but excluding Western Asset Management, there were $7.4 billion in long-term net inflows.
3. The company's institutional pipeline of won-but-unfunded mandates reached $20.4 billion as of March 31, 2025, its highest level since 2022.

1. At the Williams Companies, Inc. 2025 Annual Meeting on April 29, 2025, all eleven director nominees were elected, although significant opposition votes were cast against several, ranging from 3.5% to 15.8% of total votes.
2.  Advisory approval of named executive officer compensation received 942,887,429 votes for and 34,451,433 votes against, representing approximately 96% approval.
3. Ernst & Young LLP was ratified as the company's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025, with over 95% of the vote.
1. Q1 2025 revenue increased 25% year-over-year to $237.8 million, driven by higher trading volumes and increased Section 31 fees.
2. Cboe Global Markets Inc. debt increased by $18.4 million to $1,335.4 million between December 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025.
3. The SEC dismissed its climate disclosure rules on March 27, 2025, following legal challenges.
1. Hubbell Inc. acquired Ventev for $73 million in Q1 2025, contributing to a $48 million increase in goodwill by March 31, 2025.
2. Q1 2025 net sales decreased 2.4% year-over-year to $1,365.2 million, while restructuring charges decreased from $5.2 million in Q1 2024 to $1.7 million in Q1 2025.
3.  Hubbell Inc. expects a total of $7 million in restructuring costs for 2025 and $73.9 million in amortization expense for definite-lived intangible assets for the remainder of 2025.

1. Bunge Global SA's wholly-owned subsidiary, Bunge Limited Finance Corp. (BLFC), extended the expiration date of its exchange offers and consent solicitations from May 5, 2025, to June 13, 2025,  pending the completion of Bunge's acquisition of Viterra.
2. As of May 2, 2025,  between 95.7% and 99.4% of the principal amount of outstanding Viterra Notes had been validly tendered in the exchange offers.
3.  BLFC anticipates further extending the expiration date if Bunge's acquisition of Viterra isn't completed by June 13, 2025.

1. Hologic experienced a significant year-over-year decline in net income, reporting a net loss of $17.4 million for the three months ended March 29, 2025, compared to a net income of $169.9 million in the same period of 2024.
2.  The company anticipates a $20 to $25 million negative impact on quarterly results starting in Q4 2025 due to new tariffs on imported goods.
3.  As of March 29, 2025, Hologic had $973.1 million remaining in its new $1.5 billion stock repurchase program.
1. PPL Corp reaffirmed its 2025 earnings guidance range of $1.75 to $1.87 per share (midpoint $1.81) during May 2025 meetings with analysts and investors.
2.  The company will make its presentation slides available on its website (investors.pplweb.com/events) beginning May 2, 2025.
3. No future impacts or risks are specified in this section of the filing.
1. Take-Two Interactive Software, Inc. announced that the release date of Grand Theft Auto VI has been pushed back from Fall 2025 to May 26, 2026.
2. The company reiterated its expectation to achieve sequential increases and record levels of net bookings in fiscal years 2026 and 2027.
3. Take-Two plans to report its fourth-quarter and fiscal 2025 results on May 15, 2025.

1. Cboe Global Markets, Inc. reported record quarterly net revenue of $565.2 million and record diluted EPS of $2.37 for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, representing a 13% and 21% year-over-year increase respectively.
2.  The company increased its 2025 organic total net revenue growth target to mid to high single digits from a previous mid-single-digit projection.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, Cboe Global Markets had approximately $649.8 million of availability remaining under its share repurchase program.
1. T. Rowe Price's Q1 2025 diluted EPS decreased by $0.34 (14%) to $2.15, compared to $2.49 in Q1 2024.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, AUM decreased by $40.3 billion, driven by net cash outflows of $8.6 billion and negative market appreciation of $31.7 billion.
3. T. Rowe Price forecasts a full-year 2025 effective tax rate between 23.5% and 27.5% (GAAP), and 24.0% and 27.0% (adjusted).
1. Eaton Corp plc reported record first-quarter 2025 earnings per share of $2.45 (up 20% year-over-year) and adjusted earnings per share of $2.72 (up 13% year-over-year).

2.  Organic sales growth accelerated to 9% in Q1 2025, exceeding the high end of guidance, while full-year 2025 EPS is expected to be between $10.29 and $10.69 (a 10% increase at the midpoint from 2024).
3. Eaton acquired Fibrebond Corporation for $1.45 billion on April 1, 2025, a U.S.-based company with $378 million in sales in the twelve months prior to the acquisition.
1. Exxon Mobil's first-quarter 2025 earnings were $7.7 billion, down from $8.2 billion in the first quarter of 2024.
2.  ExxonMobil achieved $12.7 billion in cumulative structural cost savings since 2019 (as of May 2nd, 2025), exceeding the combined savings of other IOCs.
3. ExxonMobil expects 10 advantaged projects to generate over $3 billion in earnings in 2026 (at constant 2024 prices and margins).

1. Chevron reported Q1 2025 earnings of $3.5 billion, down from $5.5 billion in Q1 2024, primarily due to lower income from affiliates, lower refined product sales margins, unfavorable tax and foreign exchange effects, and lower realizations.
2.  Year-over-year, Chevron's free cash flow decreased significantly to $1.3 billion in Q1 2025 from $2.7 billion in Q1 2024.
3. Chevron aims to achieve industry-leading free cash flow growth by 2026 and reduce structural costs by $2-3 billion by the end of 2026.
1. Cigna Group's total revenues for the first quarter of 2025 increased by 14% year-over-year to $65.5 billion.
2.  The company's 2025 adjusted income from operations outlook increased to at least $29.60 per share, a $0.10 increase from the prior projection.

3. The divestiture of Cigna Group's Medicare businesses to HCSC on March 19, 2025, decreased total medical customers by 6% from December 31, 2024, to 18.0 million; however, excluding this transaction, medical customer numbers remained consistent.
1. DuPont de Nemours, Inc. reported a GAAP loss from continuing operations of $(548) million for the first quarter of 2025, primarily due to a $768 million non-cash goodwill impairment charge.
2.  First-quarter 2025 net sales increased 5% year-over-year to $3.1 billion, driven by a 6% increase in organic sales.
3.  DuPont maintains its full-year 2025 financial guidance, but notes an expected $60 million (or $0.10 per share) net cost impact from tariffs.
1. Apple's net income increased by 5% year-over-year to $24.78 billion for the quarter ending March 29, 2025.
2.  Apple repurchased 208 million shares for $48.3 billion in the six months ending March 29, 2025.
3.  $26.3 billion in unrecognized compensation costs related to RSUs, as of March 29, 2025, is projected to be recognized over the next 2.7 years.
1. As of May 1st, 2025, News Corp had repurchased approximately US$668,014,067.68 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On May 1st, 2025,  21,706,033 Class A shares and 10,713,813 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$442,720,448.12 and US$224,702,415.26 in consideration, respectively.
3.  News Corp's stock repurchase program, authorizing the acquisition of up to US$1 billion of outstanding shares,  is ongoing and subject to market conditions.
1. GoDaddy's Q1 2025 revenue increased 7.7% year-over-year to $1,194.3 million, but net income dropped significantly to $219.5 million, partly due to a one-time benefit in 2024.
2.  GoDaddy's net income decreased by $182 million year-over-year in Q1 2025.
3.  GoDaddy may need to raise capital via debt or equity financing for future acquisitions or share repurchases.
1. Amgen incurred an $800 million intangible asset impairment charge in Q1 2025 due to the Inflation Reduction Act's earlier-than-expected impact on Otezla.
2.  Amgen's Q1 2025 product sales increased 11% year-over-year, driven by volume growth despite a 6% decline in net selling price.
3. Biosimilar competition is expected to erode Amgen's sales in the second half of 2025, with a Fresenius Kabi biosimilar launching in the US as early as June 30, 2025.

1. Amazon's Q1 2025 net income surged 65% year-over-year to $17.1 billion,  driven by increased sales and a reclassification adjustment, despite a $162 million negative impact from revised depreciation estimates.
2.  Amazon increased its Commercial Paper Programs by $10 billion to $30 billion in April 2025.
3. Amazon is appealing a jury verdict with currently unspecified financial implications.
1. On April 30, 2025, Corning Incorporated's President and Chief Operating Officer, Eric S. Musser, announced his retirement, effective mid-2025, after 39 years with the company.

2.  Corning Incorporated appointed Avery H. Nelson III as Executive Vice President (immediately) and Chief Operating Officer (upon Musser's retirement), and Wendell P. Weeks as President (upon Musser's retirement), in addition to his existing roles as Chairman and CEO.

3.  Several other executive appointments were made on April 30, 2025, including Lewis A. Steverson as Vice Chairman and John Z. Zhang as Executive Vice President and Chief Corporate Development Officer, each expanding existing roles with new responsibilities.
1. DexCom's net income for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, decreased by 28% year-over-year to $105.4 million.
2.  As of April 24, 2025, DexCom had 392,107,501 shares outstanding, and the company authorized a $750 million share repurchase program expiring no later than June 30, 2026.
3. DexCom is evaluating the impact of three new FASB accounting pronouncements (ASU 2023-09, ASU 2024-03, and ASU 2024-04) on its financial statements.

1. AES Corporation's Q1 2025 net income decreased significantly year-over-year, from $278 million to a net loss of $73 million, primarily due to higher prior-year revenues from the Warrior Run coal plant PPA sale, restructuring costs, and a prior-year gain on Uplight dilution.
2.  Despite the Q1 2025 net loss, AES reaffirmed its 2025 guidance for Adjusted EBITDA of $2,650 to $2,850 million and Adjusted EPS of $2.10 to $2.26, as of May 1, 2025.
3.  AES achieved its full-year 2025 asset sale proceeds target of $400 to $500 million with the sale of a minority stake in AGIC for $450 million.
1. SBA Communications Corp. exited the Philippines and Colombia markets in Q1 2025, incurring an $18.2 million loss.
2.  A new $1.5 billion share repurchase plan was approved on April 27, 2025, replacing a prior plan with only $81.8 million remaining.
3.  The company anticipates $1.255 billion to $1.275 billion in discretionary capital expenditures for 2025, contingent on acquisitions and new tower construction.

1. Mettler-Toledo's reported sales declined 5% year-over-year to $883.7 million in Q1 2025, while local currency sales decreased by 3%, although this increased to 3% growth excluding the impact of delayed shipments in Q1 2024.
2.  Adjusted EPS for Q1 2025 was $8.19, an 8% decrease year-over-year.
3. Management forecasts 0% to 1% local currency sales growth for Q2 2025, and Adjusted EPS growth of -2% to 1%,  influenced by a projected 3% headwind from higher tariff costs in Q2.
1. Motorola Solutions' Q1 2025 net earnings of $430 million represent a substantial turnaround from a $39 million net loss in Q1 2024.
2.  The company's acquisitions of five businesses, totaling $700 million as of May 6, 2025, may impact future profitability.
3. New global tariffs implemented in February 2025 are expected to increase Motorola Solutions' costs, though the company plans to mitigate these increases.
1. Grainger's net sales increased by 1.7% year-over-year to $4,306 million in the three months ended March 31, 2025.
2.  Ongoing litigation with KMCO, LLC poses an uncertain risk with potentially significant losses for Grainger.
3.  A quarterly dividend of $2.26 per share was declared on April 30, 2025, payable June 1, 2025.
1. Biogen's Q1 2025 net income decreased by 39.3% year-over-year, to a loss of $152.9 million, primarily due to increased costs and decreased MS product revenue.

2. Biogen anticipates $1 billion in gross operating expense savings by the end of 2025 from its 2023 Fit for Growth program, but also expects a $50-$100 million revenue reduction due to the Inflation Reduction Act.
3. Biogen committed to a $1.5 billion lease for new headquarters space starting May 31, 2028.
1. Consolidated Edison's net income for common stock increased by $71 million year-over-year to $791 million in the three months ending March 31, 2025.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Consolidated Edison Transmission's $530 million investment in Mountain Valley Pipeline has a carrying value of only $164 million.

3.  Con Edison's pending rate increase requests, totaling $1.61 billion for electric and $349 million for gas in 2026,  await NYSPSC approval and will significantly impact the company's financial condition.
1. Con Edison's Q1 2025 net income increased by $71 million compared to Q1 2024, reaching $791 million ($2.26 per share).
2.  Con Edison plans to file a rate case in Q2 2025 to recover approximately $4 billion in capital investments.
3. The company forecasts adjusted earnings per share of $5.50 to $5.70 for 2025 (as of May 1st, 2025).
1. Ameren Corporation reported Q1 2025 GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.07, compared to $0.98 in Q1 2024, and adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.07 compared to $1.02 in Q1 2024.

2.  The year-over-year increase in Ameren Missouri's Q1 2025 earnings ($42 million vs. $25 million GAAP and $36 million adjusted in Q1 2024) was primarily driven by higher retail sales due to colder winter temperatures, partially offset by increased interest and storm-related expenses.

3. Ameren reaffirmed its 2025 diluted earnings per share guidance range of $4.85 to $5.05, contingent upon normal temperatures for the remainder of the year and various regulatory, economic, and operational factors.
1. On May 1, 2025, Procter & Gamble closed an underwritten public offering of $700,000,000 in 4.050% Notes due May 1, 2030, and $550,000,000 in 4.600% Notes due May 1, 2035.
2. Legal opinions regarding the notes were filed as Exhibits (5)(a) and (5)(b).
3.  The offering raised a total of $1,250,000,000 in new debt.
1. IDEX Corp's Q1 2025 diluted earnings per share decreased by 21% year-over-year to $1.26, despite a 2% overall increase in net sales.
2.  IDEX expects to incur between $3.5 and $7.5 million in additional restructuring charges during the remainder of 2025 (as of May 2nd, 2025).
3. The Mott Corporation acquisition resulted in a $4.2 million purchase price reduction for IDEX, with funds received in January 2025.
1. Camden Property Trust's Q1 2025 diluted EPS was $0.36, significantly lower than the $0.77 reported in Q1 2024.
2.  Q1 2025 same-store NOI growth significantly exceeded the full-year 2025 projection, with various reports citing growth between 12.6% and 15.3%.
3. Camden plans to add approximately 1,800 apartment units in 2025 and 2026.
1. On May 1, 2025, Fredric J. Tomczyk retired as CEO of Cboe Global Markets, Inc., to be replaced by Craig Donohue, effective May 7, 2025.

2. Mr. Donohue will receive an annual base salary of $1,300,000, a target bonus of 150% (prorated for 2025), a target long-term incentive award valued at $10,050,000 (prorated for 2025), and a sign-on equity award valued at $6,000,000.
3. Mr. Donohue's employment agreement has an initial term expiring May 7, 2030, automatically renewing annually unless either party provides 180 days' written notice of non-extension.

1. Ingersoll Rand Inc. reported record first-quarter orders ($1,882 million, up 10% year-over-year), revenue ($1,717 million, up 3% year-over-year), and free cash flow ($223 million, up 124% year-over-year) as of March 31, 2025.
2.  The company revised its full-year 2025 Adjusted EBITDA guidance downward from $2,130M-$2,190M to $2,070M-$2,130M, and its Adjusted EPS guidance to ~$flat - +3% YoY growth, as of May 1, 2025.
3. Ingersoll Rand plans to repurchase up to $750 million of its shares by the end of 2025.
1. On May 1, 2025, Constellation Brands issued $500 million in 4.800% Senior Notes due 2030, at a public offering price of 99.824% of the principal amount.
2.  The Notes mature on May 1, 2030, and interest is payable semi-annually, commencing November 1, 2025.
3. The Supplemental Indenture contains customary events of default, including default in payment of principal or interest, and specific events involving bankruptcy or insolvency.
